The warranty period is 24 months for private use, 12 months for commercial or professional use or equivalent wear and tear. The warranty period begins with the purchase by the first buyer. The decisive date is the date on the original purchase receipt. For all tools purchased from September 1, 2004 onwards, which are intended for professional use and are blue (excluding high-frequency tools, industrial battery-powered screwdrivers, and pneumatic tools), the warranty period is extended to 36 months if the buyer registers the tools within 4 weeks of the purchase date. Battery packs and chargers, as well as accessories delivered with the tools, are excluded from this extended warranty. Registration can only be made online at [www.bosch-pt.com/warranty](http://www.bosch-pt.com/warranty). The confirmation of registration is the registration receipt, which must be printed immediately, as well as the original purchase receipt, which shows the date of purchase. Registration is only possible if the buyer agrees to the storage of his data there. Excluded from the warranty are: parts that are subject to normal wear and tear, as well as defects in the tool that are due to normal use, unusual environmental conditions, unusual operating conditions, overloading, or insufficient maintenance or care. Defects in the tool caused by the use of non-Bosch accessory parts, replacement parts, or spare parts. Tools that have undergone modifications or additions. Minor deviations from the specified condition that are insignificant for the value and usability of the tool. The removal of the defect recognized by us as warranty-worthy is carried out in such a way that we repair the defective tool free of charge or replace it with a flawless tool (possibly also a subsequent model) at our discretion. Replaced tools or parts become our property.

translation2: Tire Choice for Racing Bikes - Really That Safe? I've been eagerly awaiting today, because I wanted to prepare for my upcoming cycling tour next week by at least a little bit of training. Said and done, and I went out on my racing bike, which I bought yesterday on eBay. The first 40km were great too - but then what happened, what lurks in every city center (this time: Thanks Krefeld!) happened. Glass shards on the route. Zack, loud hissing and my rear tire didn't want to continue the rest of the route on no account. Since I couldn't really get a replacement tire and tube on Wednesday due to the day of the week, I had to turn around with half-hearted mood and take the first train home. It wasn't quite as bad weather-wise, maybe it's better if I practice the tire change before the tour. Now I stand before a question and hope that you can help me. Since I have a relatively long route over several days ahead of me, I would extremely unwillingly have this problem again and again. Now it wasn't really bad, because also the old tires from the previous owner (very nice old man, who had driven 140km on the day I picked up the bike until 14:12!) and he also already described them as suboptimal because he had driven with them for years. But if I think about the fact that I have to change the tire after 80-90km, then I'm afraid I'm really in a bad mood :D Now I've had a conversation with an older man at the platform who asked me why I didn't have Marathon Plus tires; these are supposed to be unbreakable. That sounds very tempting. But are they really that indestructible? I don't want to spend 40€/tire now to find out that I'm disappointed. I continue to wonder: I currently have 25x622 on my bike, which is apparently also available (apparently?) with Marathon Plus tires, but the majority is already wider. Is this a problem? Or would you advise me to other tires with a racing bike in general? The Schwalbe side seems to be my absolute! My knowledge of the topic is rather in favor of the Durano DD. Thank you already in advance for the help and warm greetings!

reference: Picking tires for a road bike - life without popped tires? This morning I woke up with a fiery drive because I still wanted to at least train a bit in the upcoming weeks in preparation for my upcoming bicycle tour. It was as easy as that and I drove my road bike which I had bought on eBay the day before. The first 40 km were really beautiful - but then that happened which is always waiting for you in the intercity (this time: thanks goes to Krefeld!). Glass shards on the road. Pop, a loud hiss and my back tire was no longer up for riding the rest of the trip. Because of it being a work day, I didn’t really have the chance to acquire a spare tire and tube, I had to turn back halfway through in a bad mood and take the next workable train back home. It was not the worst downer ever, maybe it is even better if I practice changing tires one more time before I leave to go on the tour. But now I am posed with a question and hope that you will be able to help me. Because I have a relatively long stretch of road and many days in front of me, I would very much like to not run into this problem on a regular basis. This time it really wasn’t that bad, because the tires were from the previous owner (a very nice old man, who had already rode 120 km by 2 PM on the day I came to pick up my bicycle) and because he had described them as suboptimal, because he had already been wearing them down for many years. But if I think about having to change tires every 80-90 km on the tour, then I am already in a really bad mood :D I just got into a discussion with an older man at the train platform, who asked me quite surprised, why I don’t have the Marathon Plus tires, these are supposed to be impossible to pop. Now that certainly does sound tempting. But are they really so indestructible? I have no desire to give out €40 per tire in order to just be disappointed. At the same time, I ask myself: I am using 25x622 race tires at the moment, I believe. This is (apparently?) just like the Marathon Plus tires, but the majority of tires are actually wider. Is that the real problem? Or would you recommend that I really get different tires in general for the road bike? The Schwalbe website seems to be of one opinion! Would common sense tend to recommend the Durano DD? Thank you in advance for your help and take care!

translation2: "The party we wanted to throw": Frankfurt celebrates after a torrid comeback against Leverkusen What a spectacular reaction from Eintracht Frankfurt. After 22 minutes, the last time they won twice in a row, it seemed that the Hesse were on their way to another Bundesliga failure. But then the SGE turned it around, shot off their frustration over a mediocre season start within an hour and won wildly with 5:2. "It's crazy what the guys have done today," jubiled coach Oliver Glasner to DAZN and gave a "general compliment to everyone who was there," expressing admiration for their performance. It initially looked like another dampener for the Frankfurt team, who are still behind their expectations in ninth place. Patrik Schick had given Leverkusen a 2-0 lead. But what happened next impressed even the SGE coach. "How the players came back and showed a fantastic performance," Glasner continued. I am crazy happy with the performance we showed and of course with the result. Even defender Christopher Lenz, who was able to play again for the first time since the fourth game week and his injured muscle, emphasized the morale of his teammates. "I believe our mentality is incredible," said the 27-year-old and was particularly pleased for the fans with the result. That was the party we wanted to throw. But for the upcoming tasks, Glasner wants to keep the focus on himself, and he feels well prepared in terms of personnel. It is extraordinary that all players are fit in December and in top physical condition. It is top work in our medical department, but the players also live highly professionally. Now you want to "take it step by step and stay humble" and go through the tasks until the end of the year "at this level." The next game is already scheduled for Wednesday, as part of the English week, an away game at Borussia Mönchengladbach (18:30, Sky).

In the F1 there was even knowledge gaps of the rules in the commentary by Sascha Roos and Ralf Schumacher, both of them didn’t know that during a red flag the tires are allowed to be changed. Although this situation already came up this year in Imola, Baku and Silverstone, they both first came to the conclusion that Verstappen was allowed to switch his tires following corresponding radio messages on the topic to Hamilton. The announcers at Sky UK and RTL knew immediately that this was a possibility for Verstappen. I am of the opinion that knowledge of such elementary rules should be assumed if you are going to provide F1 commentary on a paid-for TV broadcaster. It's also not the first guessing game as to what is possible or required by the rules, both of them have constant uncertainties regarding rules. In general I don’t really like the artificial style of the commentary from Roos, but I’ll admit that is a manner of taste. But even Heiko Wasser from RTL does it better in my honest opinion. Additionally, there are just absurdities, which make the two of them seem unprofessional, like the ordering of coffee with the (just as clueless) reporter Peter Hardenacke or the “Ahhhh HD” from Ralf Schumacher. This last part really brings a lot of agitation into the commentary which he doesn’t take seriously. Not least of all, the advertising is just so prevalent on Sky, in the cool-down lap Sky is the only broadcaster that still goes to commercials, like you can hear this on F1TV, because only the German audio track comes out without commentary right after the race. Neither ServusTV nor ORF do this. Both of these broadcasters also do less commercials than Sky during training, and they are free TV broadcasters. You even have to congratulate Glock and Baumgartner for their work, but that alone doesn’t cause me to overlook the disadvantages. The normal program from Sky Sport F1 is also very sparse and full of repetitions. All in all, Sky is really the worst German-speaking broadcaster that transmits the F1. In all honesty, RTL does a better job of transmitting the four races which they are allowed to transmit, including even the advertisements. At any rate, it really makes the grand F1 season considerably less fun as would be the case with a reasonable broadcaster. I would be really interested in your opinion.

translation2: I find it generally unfair to expect children to take on the role of parents for their younger siblings. However, I do think it's good for older siblings to take care of their younger siblings to some extent. They can take turns keeping an eye on them, helping out, and even bringing them a drink, for example. This way, they learn responsibility, help out in the family, and feel included. As long as they are still capable of taking care of themselves, I don't see a problem with it. If your K1 is occupied for a short time and it's okay for him, that's fine. You can best assess whether it's suitable for your children. It's not like he has to take care of K2 all the time and stay with him until he falls asleep. Legally, it may be questionable. Perhaps that's why the psychologist's statement comes into play. If something were to happen like a fire, burglary, earthquake, alien invasion, etc., it would be too much responsibility for K1 to take care of K2. Whether you want to take that risk is, of course, up to you :)
reference: I also think that as a general rule, children should not be expected to overtake a parental role for their younger siblings. However, I think it is also good for older siblings to care for the younger ones to some degree. Sometimes check-up on them, sometimes help, sometimes get the bottle, etc. They learn responsibility this way, help within the family and are thus connected with it. As long as they can continue to be a kid themselves, I don’t see the problem. If your first child looks after themselves alone for a short amount of time, that is OK, that is actually good. You can best get a sense of whether or not this works for your children. It is not as if they should change the second child’s diaper and sit for hours by them as they fall asleep. It is probably questionable from a strictly legal perspective. Maybe the psychologist would also have something to say about it. Since if something actually does happen, like a fire, break-in, earthquake, alien invasion, etc., it would be too much responsibility for child 1 to take care of child 2. If that is a risk that you would like to take that is up to you, of course ;)

translation2: Heavy "Huidlerer" question: The Amberg man knows the solution What please is an "Huidlerer"? With this dialect word, sent by an Amberg man, heated thinking has been aroused in the BR television show "We in Bavaria". But unlike on many previous days, the term "Host mi?" this time remained unguessed by the callers. No, it was not a "person who is nervous". And neither was it "one who everything has to go quickly for". That, the people heard from the TV moderator, was completely wrong. Whereupon the man from Amberg revealed the solution and thus probably also surprised many Upper Palatinate people. "The Huidlerer", the viewers learned, "is a cloth used to wipe the oven". Dialectologist Antony Rowley, who has been consulted by Bavarian Television for years as an expert, confirmed this. With the remark that this is a typical Upper Palatinate term, derived somehow from the better known dialect word "Houdern". With which a gap in education was closed - perhaps also for many who have been living in the Amberg area for a long time.

translation2: Friedrich Wins 60th World Cup Victory - Nolte Wins Two-Man Bob - Sport  The brand of the Norwegian biathlete Ole Einar Björndalen with 94 victories is the goal of the bobsled pilot. "I've calculated it, I would need to win nine and a half races per season to make it to Cortina 2026," said the double Olympic champion from BSC Oberbärenburg, who scored two victories in two days of racing in Winterberg. First, he fended off an attack by Johannes Lochner by five hundredths of a second, overtaking him from third to first. Then he made some changes to the equipment settings and posted a larger lead of 0.30 seconds on Sunday. With his teammates Thorsten Margis (SV Halle), Candy Bauer (BSC Oberbärenburg), and Alexander Schüller (SV Halle), he beat the British Brad Hall. Third place went to Austrian Benjamin Maier. "We took a bigger risk today and were rewarded," said Friedrich, who also scored his 22nd consecutive victory. The Stuttgart-based Berchtesgadener Johannes Lochner finished fifth after placing second earlier. Christoph Hafer from BC Bad Feilnbach landed in eighth place after finishing fourth in the first race. "If I knew what he was doing differently, I would do the same," said Lochner.  Nolte Wins Home Race - Podium for Jamanka  At the women's event, Laura Nolte won her third season victory in the two-man bob on her home track. After finishing fourth in the monobob the day before, she raced to the World Cup victory with her pusher Deborah Levi on Sunday. Two-man bob Olympic champion Mariama Jamanka from BRC Thüringen finished second with Germany's fastest sprinter, Alexandra Burghardt from Burghausen. Jamanka also qualified for the Olympics with her performance, scoring her first podium finish this winter. Wiesbadener Kim Kalicki finished third with Leonie Fiebig. "It was super cool to get my first podium in the World Cup," said Burghardt, emphasizing that it's not just about pushing, but there's also a lot to do around it. Jamanka was a bit frustrated with the not entirely flawless runs, but said, "It's going in the right direction."
